oai:www.e-space.mmu.ac.uk:2173/75856</identifier><datestamp>2009-07-29T12:26:14Z</datestamp><setSpec>hdl_2173_23540</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd" ><dc:title>Reconciling subjects and contexts: the case for a pragmatic primary curriculum</dc:title><dc:creator>Smith, John</dc:creator><dc:subject>Primary</dc:subject><dc:subject>Curriculum</dc:subject><dc:subject>Subject-teaching</dc:subject><dc:subject>Topic-teaching</dc:subject><dc:description>In this paper the author examines changes in the primary curriculum in this country since the
time of the Plowden Report of 1967. Since that time there have been several changes of
emphasis from teaching through subjects to teaching through contexts. The author
considers some of the reasons for this oscillation and suggests some principles which a
renewed primary curriculum might be constructed upon. The author also suggests that a
renewed curriculum should place much greater emphasis upon the use of spoken language
in the classroom and that much more consideration needs to be given to the challenges
which change curriculum change poses for practitioners. For a number of reasons, it is
suggested that the term ‘pragmatic’ might be a good label for the curriculum of the future.</dc:description><dc:description>Full-text of this article is available at http://www.educationstudies.org.uk/materials/vol_1_issue_2_j_smith_final.pdf</dc:description><dc:publisher>British Education Studies Association (BESA)</dc:publisher><dc:date>2009-07-29T13:26:13Z</dc:date><dc:type>Article</dc:type><dc:identifier>Educational futures, 2008, vol. 1, no. 2, pp. 63-74</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>1758-2199</dc:identifier><dc:identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/2173/75856</dc:identifier><dc:language>en</dc:language><dc:relation>http://www.educationstudies.org.uk/journal/</dc:relation><dc:relation>http://www.educationstudies.org.uk/materials/vol_1_issue_2_j_smith_final.pdf</dc:relation></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record>
